Bakugou can control his quirk. That’s a fact. Like, the sky is blue and water is wet. He’s not like fucking Deku or that stupid round face who’s constantly throwing up. He can control it, always has. Bakugou prides himself on his control. That doesn’t mean that sometimes controlling his quirk gets a little harder. Like, for example, when it’s the middle of summer and he’s a constant mess of sweat.


It almost burns in a way, itches. It makes Bakugou want to wipe his palms all over his school pants but he learnt a long time ago not to do that. Just because he only produces the explosive sweat in his hands doesn’t mean its chemical makeup changes when he transfers it to another surface; his gauntlets would be useless if that were the case. But no, he’s cursed in the way that wiping his hands on his trousers is basically the equivalent of smearing them in petrol and with someone like that Half-and-Half bastard in their class, he’d rather not risk it.


Plus the smell never comes out.


So he’s left to constantly wiping his hands on the packet of tissues he’s packed - in summer, not in winter like everyone else - or just trying to ignore the wet feeling. Neither option work very well though, Bakugou knows from experience. For some reason it feels as though the nitroglycerin builds up if he doesn’t expel it, makes his skin itch, burn, gnaw away at him, but he’s old enough to ignore it by now. It also doesn’t mean that the first thing he does after school is find a training ground and let off some steam.


Unfortunately for Bakugou, this summer is particularly hot and today’s temperature is hotter again. Most of the class are constantly fanning themselves. Deku’s got a towel draped around his neck that he knows Half-and-Half was kind enough to fill with ice before class. Frog Girl looks to be fairing almost as well as he is, Shitty Hair not far behind. Bakugou’s dripping with sweat and his palms ache. He’s almost been tempted to duck out to the bathrooms to rinse them off and pat them dry but he’s not that weak. He’ll make it, he tells himself with a scowl, trying to focus on his textbook. Of course, that’s when he’s distracted by a call from the front.


“Bakugou.”


His eyes briefly flick up to their teacher, lips curled back in a snarl. “What?”


Before Deku or that fucking loud-mouthed four eyes can say anything about his attitude, Aizawa is beside his desk, slapping down a folder that’s clearly filled with paper. “Do me a favour and explode this.”


Bakugou frowns, sure this is some sort of test. He cautiously places a hand on the folder and pulls it towards himself, other hand already starting to smoke. “Sure about that Teach’?”


Aizawa just stares at him so he scoffs and lifts his hand, ready to burn the papers just as he’d done to Deku’s notebook last year. Before he can though, Aizawa is rolling his eyes. “Explode Bakugou,” he reprimands, “Not singe. The windows open, by the way.”


The last line is almost a throw away but it has Bakugou grinning. This he can do. He all but hurls the window open before jumping onto the ledge outside. His grin is borderline manic as he unleashes the full power of his quirk, amplified as it is by the sheer amount of sweat he’s amassed. The resulting blast is big, bigger even than the one he used at the Sports Festival. There come some soft gasps from inside but Bakugou barely hears them, revelling in the feeling of relief pulsating from his hands. That unbearable itch is gone and his head feels clearer. He jumps back into the classroom and throws himself into his chair with a triumphant smirk. He cocks an eyebrow at Aizawa but the bastard just holds up the slightest scrap of paper. “Missed a bit.”


Two seconds later the paper is smouldering in Bakugou’s hands and completely illegible. “Not anymore.”


Bakugou doesn’t need to know that the paper was blank to start with, that all of it was. Just grabbed from under the desk and shoved into a folder specifically for him to explode. It isn’t as though Aizawa noticed his dilemma and cared enough to lend a hand. Definitely not.

 

***


It takes Aizawa a little while to notice. At first it just slips under his radar but the more Midoriya ends up in either Recovery’s Girl office or the hospital - which is disturbingly a lot - the more he has to call Midoriya Inko. He doesn’t mind that in itself, the woman’s polite and quick to arrive, if not a little too flustered for his liking, but it makes Aizawa sharply aware of the gaping hole. Because yes, he’s become more than well acquainted with Mrs. Midoriya. Mr. Midoriya, however, is a mystery. 


Every time Midoriya’s unwell or injured, it’s his mother who comes and gets him. She signed him out of the police station after the Shigaraki incident and even when the whole dorm situation came up, when Toshinori had left the apartment it had only been the two of them waving him goodbye from the balcony. 


It’s enough to grab Aizawa’s interest, especially as Father’s Day approaches, and so he finds himself heading down to administration and pulling out Midoriya’s file. Of course he’d flicked through all his students’ papers upon admission but he’d more been looking at quirks and general comments from past teachers rather than emergency contacts. His eyebrows shoot up when he sees that Midoriya’s emergency contacts after his mother are Bakugou’s parents. That, he never would have suspected. 


He turns back a few pages to the family details section and yes, there’s a name there under ‘father’ - Midoriya Hisashi, it reads - but nothing more. No phone number, no address, no job description. Aizawa almost finds himself thinking it’s a shame, Midoriya’s such a loving child after all.


He then realises what he’s doing and scolds himself, letting the file snap shut only to immediately open it back up when he sees something he’d missed on his first readthrough. It’s obviously been attempted to be rubbed out but a slight indentation is still there; a third entry under emergency contacts. But still, there’s enough there for Aizawa to figure when it was headed. 


Y--i Toshi--ri


The phone number in the next column is illegible but it makes him pause nonetheless. Yagi Toshinori, All Might. Midoriya had started to write that? - it’s his handwriting, Aizawa recognises it easily. Why did he have Toshinori’s personal number? Did Midoriya start to write only to realise it would look odd to the school board? Had he started and then panicked, thinking his mother might check the forms one last time before handing them in? Because Aizawa knows that however deep Midoriya’s and Toshinori’s relationship is, Midoriya Inko doesn’t understand the full extent of it. Not that he does either but at least he knows it exists. He also feels it explains quite a lot. 


As the days drew closer to Father’s Day, it’s easier to watch Midoriya become more and more despondent. Only by a tad and unnoticeable to his peers, hidden by bright smiles and genuine interest in their plans, but Aizawa isn’t a student. He’s older and wiser and knows all the tricks. But that is definitely not why he stops by a tiny florist located on his street on his way into work that Friday morning. It also isn’t why he asks Midoriya to stay behind after class as everyone else heads to lunch. Aizawa sees Uraraka and Iida waiting at the door but Midoriya waves them on with a sheepish gesture.


He’s stammering as he approaches the desk but at least he’s not nervously twisting his hands together like he’d been doing at the start of the year. “W-what did you, uh, need, Mr. Aizawa?”


He barely bats an eyelid before grabbing the bouquet out from the same place he hides his sleeping bag, dumping it in Midoriya’s incredulous arms. “Someone told me to pass them to All Might but honestly, I can’t be bothered.”


Midoriya is furiously muttering under his breath, trying to guess who they came from, but he snaps to when Aizawa makes to leave. “Wait! Aren’t...aren’t you going to the staff room? C-couldn’t you-”


“Midoriya.”


The boy yelps and takes off, dashing past him and barrelling up the hallway. By the time Aizawa reaches the staff office, hurricane Midoriya is already gone but his fellow staff are gossiping like the mature, bored adults they are. He has the story all but screamed at him by Hizashi, how Midoriya had bumbled in, thrust the flowers at Toshinori with some butchered, stammered explanation of “these are for you”, leaving Toshinori stunned while Nemuri had cooed something about “Dad Might”. Aizawa has to bite down a smirk because this has gone better than planned; he’s so relieved Midoriya forgot to mention the all important I’m-On-A-Job-From-Aizawa-And-I-Didn’t-Actually-Buy-These.


Aizawa doesn’t care that Toshinori has tears in his eyes and asks Nezu to extend his lunch break all so he can buy a vase. He doesn’t care that when Monday rolls around Midoriya tells his friends he did “nothing much” on the weekend but Aizawa’s already been bombarded with stories from Toshinori about how they saw the sights of Tokyo together. He doesn’t care that Toshinori’s name gets added into Midoriya’s enrolment file, only in the man’s own handwriting this time. He really doesn’t care at all.


***





It’s a well known fact that animals can sense storms before they arrive. And although Kaminari is no animal, the same rings true for him. It’s the first period after lunch when his proverbial ears prick up and he starts feeling the static in the air. A quick glance out the window shows no visible clouds and he bites back a groan, knowing what that means: this storm is going to be bad.


It’s not that Kaminari doesn’t like storms, he has nothing against them and actually enjoys the thrill of the thunder claps and the beauty of the lightning as it dances across the sky or touches down, but he does have a problem with the way they interfere with his quirk. He becomes akin to a woollen jumper and is completely overloaded with static. Everyone who so much as touches him gets an unpleasant zap, although Kaminari keeps a tight enough reign that it’s never enough to actually hurt them. It’s still a pain though, makes his body feel like it’s running at one hundred and ten percent, makes him restless and more twitchy than normal.


By the time class is dismissed, the storm still hasn’t come, although it’s visible on the horizon. Kaminari wants nothing more than to find an open-field so he can discharge freely but then the worst thing happens: some high up in the administration part of the school declares a storm warning and every student is required to return to their dorm and stay there until the all clear is given. 


“Aw man” Kirishima whines from behind him. “Bakugou and I were gonna-” His sentence turns into a yelp when he claps Kaminari on the back and consequently gets zapped. 


“Ah, sorry, sorry!” Kaminari says, scratching the back of his neck before pointing at the sky. “It’s...you know…”


Kirishima nods but Bakugou scoffs as he storms past, brow furrowed. “Learn to control your fucking quirk instead of making shitty excuses.”


Kaminari pouts at him but the blond doesn’t even spare him so much as a glance. Kirishima gives an apologetic shrug before racing after Bakugou, muttering something about making ramen and right, Kirishima had finally convinced Bakugou to come to his favourite ramen place. Looks like the storm had put a dampener on that too. Kaminari sighs as he adjusts his bag and follows everyone back to the dorms. He waves wearily at the common room, hears Jirou offer up some excuse, before he trudges up to his room and face-plants on his bed.


A few hours later the storm is still raging, although the worst has passed, and Kaminari feels like he’s going to explode, groaning in pain on his bed. Overuse of his quirk leaves his brain without enough electricity to function, but it’s the exact opposite here and underuse is starting to kick into overdrive. He feels like a battery being charged, then over-charged, and then charged some more. Kaminari wants to just let it all out but his room is hardly insulated against lightning and he doesn’t fancy having to replace everything or risk starting a fire. He could sneak outside, but knowing his luck Aizawa would find him and he really doesn’t want to slapped with detention. Again.


Speaking of the devil does in fact summon him, Aizawa’s voice booming through the dorm’s PA system and informing them they’re having a hero lesson now, and they have ten minutes to arrive at Field Gamma.


It’s a mad scramble of students then, everyone trying to find suitable clothes given they don’t have time to collect their costumes from the classroom. Some are midway through dinner, others already in their pyjamas, and Kaminari momentarily wonders if he could just not turn up. Every move brings him pain and he’s so super-charged that he doesn’t think he’ll be able to keep his friends safe should they choose to touch him.


He does, however, eventually decide to join and is one of the last at the training field. Not dead last though, which is a relief. No, that’s Satou who looks horrified but explains he was baking and didn’t want to burn the cake. No one should be this good, Kaminari thinks as he finds a spot a little away from everyone but not too far to be noticeable. He feels like Aizawa is shooting him a look and Kaminari hastily glances away, preferring to look anywhere but at their teacher. 


“Right, everyone here?” Aizawa asks, leaving the headcount up to Iida before continuing. “Tonight we’re having a special training class because of the weather.”


“Weather?” Uraraka repeats in confusion.


Midoriya looks just as perplexed. “But what does weather have to do with-”


“Midoriya.” Aizawa’s voice stops him dead in his tracks. “You were the one that made the observation at USJ.”


Everyone looks at Midoriya who looks just as blank. His eyes then suddenly widen, whipping around to where Asui stands. “I said the villains didn’t know our quirks because they sent Tsu into a water area, where her quirk would be most effective!”


Aizawa nods. “Certain quirks can be enhanced by an environment. Some rely on it entirely.”


“Like Pokemon…”


The murmur comes from Bakugou of all people, though he isn’t looking at anyone else, finger tapping his lip in thought. “Pokemon?” Midoriya says, head cocked to one side before making a sharp sound of understanding. “Of course! A water based quirk works best beside an ocean or river. If your quirk allows you to control technology, it would be useless in a forest or desert.”


“That’s for you to discover on your own,” Aizawa interjects before abruptly turning to Kaminari, who jumps. “Kaminari, think you can handle playing a villain?”


Kaminari blinks a couple of times, confused. A rumble of thunder breaks the silence and oh, now it makes sense. He grins broadly, letting electricity crackle around him ominously. A few classmates back up hurriedly, Bakugou smiles wolfishly at the obvious challenge, Midoriya breaths something along the lines of “amazing” and yes, Kaminari can definitely do this. He is, in gaming terms, the rate-boosted character in this map and he’s going to win. The fact that it’s nineteen-to-one doesn’t even bother him, not when he’s allowed to released his quirk at full power. Who knows, maybe after this Bakugou will upgrade him from Pikachu to Zapdos. Now wouldn’t that be something.


***

Kirishima’s a punctual student. He may be loud and eccentric and get a little too fired up over things that don’t particularly matter, but he’s always on time. Aizawa was mildly surprised to discover he tended to be one of the first to classroom in the mornings but he would take that over Sero and Ashido’s perpetual lateness any day. 


Which is probably why he’s raising an eyebrow when Kirishima’s chair is empty that homeroom. No one has a message saying he’s unwell but then no one has seen him that morning either. Bakugou eventually begrudgingly admits to kicking his door on the way past that morning and being met with a “I’ll see you in class!” which sounds all well and good...except Kirishima isn’t here. He never made it that far, apparently. Midoriya offers to go look for him but Aizawa firmly tells him to sit down, that as a hero in training Kirishima has to look after himself and take responsibility for his own actions.


What he doesn’t tell them is that as soon as Hizashi comes in to teach English, he’s making his way across the school grounds to the dorms. 


According to the school’s swipe card records, Kirishima is still inside the building. Aizawa takes the lift up to the fourth floor, scowling, and he swears if the boy has just fallen back asleep he’s going to kill someone. Probably not Kirishima because killing students is frowned upon, but someone. He doesn’t even bother knocking on the door, just pushes it open and steps inside. 


There’s a mad scrambling and some muttered swearing. “I-I’m coming Baku-...”


Kirishima trails off at Aizawa’s flat look, cheeks flushing, and Aizawa is mildly curious as to when Bakugou became Kirishima’s closest friend. Kaminari would have been his first guess but then Bakugou is his next door neighbour so maybe that explains it. Closest indeed.


What isn’t explained is the harried expression on Kirishima’s face and the fact that it looks like he’s been furiously rubbing at his eyes, possibly wiping tears away.


“Ah, sorry,” Kirishima mumbles, fumbling for his bag, swinging it over his shoulder and bowing. “I’ll make the time up-”


“Why?”


Kirishima freezes dead in his tracks before adopting a very poor attempt at a smile. “Oh, ah, nothing; it was nothing! I was just…”


Aizawa forces him to sit with a hand and then leans back on the desk, gesturing vaguely. “You skipped my class Kirishima; I’m entitled to an explanation.”


The red head starts to speak before dropping his head down, preferring to stare at his lap. “It’s stupid, alright? I know that but...last night I thought it was okay but this morning it looked so much worse and…” a hand came to tug at his hair. “It’s too brown and...and I don’t…”


Aizawa swears he is going to throw himself out the window because honestly, is he here, in this room, because this fifteen-year-old cannot handle having regrowth? He would say something but it looks like Kirishima has already told himself the same things Aizawa would say...if not ten times over. And, okay, maybe - maybe - he understands a little. Because while it’s a superficial feature, it’s what makes Kirishima Kirishima. Taking that away clearly does something; damages his self-esteem quite worrisomely if Aizawa had to guess.


(He makes a note to come back to that later.)


But on another level, he completely understands. Aizawa has seen Hizashi dressed in sweats with his hair down or in a messy ponytail and he’s still the same person but something changes. He becomes quieter in some way, softer, less likely to scream the house down. Unless there’s a spider or a cute cat video. It must be something of the same for Kirishima and Aizawa doesn’t really have the heart to be angry with him. Maybe if this was third year, but not first year. Not when this boy is just fifteen and has already been through hell and back.


Shifting his gaze to the desk behind him, Aizawa picks up a rubber band from where it’s wrapped around a stack of pens. It’ll hurt like anything to get out later but he doesn’t care that much. “Hey,” he says, Kirishima’s head snapping up. “You’re all training to be heroes, right?” he continues, making the boy freeze when he starts dragging his hair up, pulling it together and starting to twist it. “If your classmates can’t handle regrowth, what can they handle?”


Kirishima abruptly laughs there, clapping a hand over his mouth to smother it just as Aizawa secures the bun. “I guess. Yeah, I never thought about it like that.” He then cautiously brings a hand to his hair. “This is...cool? Like, I really like it! Why didn’t I think of this?!”


He mutters something about manliness that Aizawa really doesn’t pay attention to, just gets to his feet when Aizawa nudges him with a boot and, frankly, that’s good enough. 


Kirishima scoops up his bag from behind him and catches him in the hall, tucking a stray piece of hair behind his ear. Aizawa gives it a dismissive look. “Ask Yaoyorozu to make something for that.”


He gets a nod and then, “Hey! I can do that cool thing with the pins where they make an “x”, that’d be super awesome! And then they’ll look at that and not my hair and-”


Aizawa tunes him out all the way back to the classroom, hanging back as Kirishima enters because he’s on his way to the staff lounge anyway. He hears Kaminari call something along the lines of, man-buns are manly as hell!” while Kirishima asks Yaoyorozu for bobby pins. 


***


The kid has a head full of gleaming red hair the next day and a grin to match. It suits him, Aizawa supposes.

Todoroki doesn’t know this happened. Well, he does but he would prefer not to dwell on the series of bad life choices that led him here. ‘Here’ is really not that bad of a place but it does involve a cat, and a stray one at that. 


It had started a few weeks ago, with Todoroki coming back to the dorms one evening after spending the afternoon at the hospital with his mother. He’d stopped by his favourite soba place only to step out and nearly trip over a stray cat. It had stared up at him with mis-matching eyes and he’d like to say that that didn’t persuade him in any way...but it did. A scratch under the chin had been enough in his opinion and Todoroki had continued on his way.


Unfortunately, it’s now six weeks later and the cat is still following him. No one else in 1-A seems to have noticed and Todoroki wonders if they’re really cut out to be heroes if they don’t notice an actual, live cat frequenting their dorm doorstep. He doesn’t mind though, not really. And if he’s been starting to pick up a couple of tins of tuna every so often and leaving them outside, no one has to know. Todoroki’s not an idiot though, and he hasn’t named the thing. He knows once Aizawa finds out about it, the cat will be removed from the residence and shipped to god knows where.


He’s happy enough now though, even if his eyes do keep darting to the door. Because he’s let the cat into the dorms and he knows that is not allowed. Todoroki doesn’t even know why he did, just that the poor thing looked so miserable sitting out in the rain and the cold that he’d had to bring it in. Sneaking past Midoriya and Iida had been easy enough and with them oblivious, Todoroki knows he’s safe. He has half a mind to ask Yaoyorozu to make a cat bed but this is not going to continue so there’s no point. At that moment, he’s met with a pair of mis-matched eyes that crinkle shut in something akin to a smile.


No, this is not going to continue.


Absolutely and definitely not.


***


Todoroki must think he’s an idiot. He’s not. Todoroki just seems to think that.


Because Todoroki seems to think that he, Aizawa, pro hero Eraserhead, has not noticed said boy sneaking a cat onto the grounds. Todoroki’s classmates might be a little behind the eight ball but Aizawa isn’t. He’s been keeping an eye on the cat ever since it first turned up and if there’s an old blanket tucked into one of the building’s crevices, that’s neither here nor there.


However, the weather is getting colder now and while Aizawa doesn’t tend to notice - he all but lives in his sleeping bag for god’s sake - this year his students make it so that he can’t help but notice. Asui seems to find it harder and harder to stay awake in class, Bakugou can’t seem to spark up straight away and is more sullen than normal, Midoriya and Uraraka have taken to crowding around a confounded Todoroki’s left side. It makes him think about Todoroki’s cat and what to do with it since the temperature keeps dropping. It can’t live outside forever but damned if he’s adopting it. He and Hizashi already have enough, thank you very much. 


Which is why, much to his chagrin, he picks the stray up one day, tucking it into the folds of his scarf. There are some mild protests before the cat settles down, purrs rumbling against his shoulder. His class all dash to their desks the second he opens the door and Aizawa is going turn a blind eye to the cake crumbs littering the floor and the way Tokoyami’s wobbles as though someone very hurriedly climbed off of it. 


“Right, new class assignment,” he says without preamble. Iida’s hand shoots into the air but one glare from him makes the student meekly drop it again. Aizawa makes his way to Todoroki’s desk, pulling the cat out by the scruff of the neck and dumping it in the boy’s lap. “Look after that.”


There’s a beat and then stammering and protests come from all over the room. “For how long?” Midoriya asks.


“Until I say otherwise.”


“Why Todoroki?” Ashido wails.


“You’re too noisy,” Aizawa deadpans.


“Why not Kouda?”


“Cats eat rabbits Kaminari,” he answers, holding up a hand when Kouda’s starts scribbling furiously. “And straight up telling them to get along is cheating.” The writing stops.


“Why me?”


The question comes from Todoroki, who apparently hasn’t noticed that the cat in question has already curled up on his left side and that he is stroking it absently. Aizawa doesn’t want to say it’s because he’s noticed Todoroki struggles with social skills or that he doubts compassion was something he was shown as a child and so he needs to develop that skill now if he wants to be a hero. No, instead he goes with, “It looks like you.”


A minute of silence and then Midoriya is muffling giggles behind his hand, Todoroki giving him a look and Aizawa’s eyes narrow. This is not happening, not in his class, no way, no how. Yaoyorozu saves the moment though, leaning across the aisle and asking for permission before getting in a pat of her own. “What are you going to call it?”


Todoroki’s face goes blank, like this hasn’t occurred to him. It probably has but he still looks put on the spot. The rest of the class start to pipe up but before they can even finish their suggestions-


“Soba.”
